title: Notes in England and Italy.
author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody
snippet: Now Loch Vennachar (lake of the fair valley) opened upon our right, and opposite, on the left, giant Ben Ledi lifted its double-headed top, one of the four highest Bens in Scotland (3,000 feet).

title: Notes in England and Italy.
author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody
snippet: road skirted Loch Acliray, and then a valley through which a stream wound to Loch Vennachar, the Tro- sach crags continuing on our left till we came to a hotel.

title: Notes in England and Italy.
author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody
snippet: road skirted Loch Acliray, and then a valley through which a stream wound to Loch Vennachar, the Tro- sach crags continuing on our left till we came to a hotel.

title: Notes in England and Italy.
author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody
snippet: Two arched stone bridges span a river that flows from Loch Achray to Loch Yennachar.

title: Notes in England and Italy.
author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody
snippet: The broad waters of the Loch wind in great curves round the various promontories and headlands, so that constantly we seemed to see the whole, and then a turn brought to view still remoter reaches, and as we approached Ellen's Isle, the sterile mountain-sides  changed to richly-wooded steeps.

title: Notes in England and Italy.
author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody
snippet: Soon we came to Loch Winnoch.
